title: Tory conference - Cameron hardens EU stance as Ukip defection rocks party: Politics live blog | Politics | The Guardian
summary: ruth davidson hints more devolution could help tories in scotland .
villiers calls for resumption of cross-party talks in northern ireland .
tories says cutting welfare cap would cost 70,000 families £ 40pw on average .
lord ashcroft says his polling suggests labour heading for majority .

documents.title: afternoon summary
text: grant shapps , the conservative chairman , has launched a strong attack on the ukip defector mark reckless , saying that conservatives have been betrayed '' and cheated '' by someone who lied and lied and lied '' .
( see 2.12pm . )

grant shapps court/afp/getty images lord ashcroft , the billionaire former conservative party deputy chairman who now uses his fortune to commission extensive political polling , has told a fringe meeting at the conference that his latest research suggests labour could win a comfortable majority .
here 's the speech he gave , and here 's an excerpt .
in the polling i have done so far , the only gains that currently look likely for the conservatives would come from the liberal democrats .
so far i have found eight lib dem seats where the conservatives are ahead .
unfortunately i have also found eight seats which , on current polling , the lib dems would lose to labour .
that leaves no current net advantage to the tories on the lib dem battleground .
and to make matters worse , my research has found the conservatives currently on course to lose two seats to ukip .
if that situation persists , according to our formula , the conservatives can afford to lose no more than 22 seats to labour before they cease to be the largest party in the house of commons .
unfortunately , the polling i have already done in individual seats , starting with the most marginal , shows the tories already behind in 24 .
this includes brighton kemptown , enfield north and hastings & rye , three of the more defensive conservative seats i am looking at in the round of research which is currently in the field .

and the current national polls , as well as the overall swings in the conservative-labour battleground i have found so far , suggests the number of losses could extend to the point where labour have a comfortable working majority .
william hague , the leader of the commons , has used his final speech to a conservative conference as an mp to tell the party that it must remain inclusive .
there is not and must never be anything narrow about our conservatism .
that i and others can work on so many issues within a career in the conservative party shows its breadth and its unending relevance and potential .
and by the way , i 've done all this work and held so many high offices starting as i did as a comprehensive schoolboy in rotherham .
do n't anyone ever try to tell me that you have to be privileged , or come from the south , or be connected to anybody at all , in order to get to the top in the conservative party .
our party is a party for everyone .
my last advice from the conference platform is always to keep that breadth of inclusion and sense of progress for all .
william hague gadd/allstar/sportsphoto ltd./allstar the sunday mirror has come under pressure to justify the entrapment exercise that led to the resignation of brooks newmark .
ruth davidson , the scottish conservative leader , has hinted that more devolution to edinburgh could make the scots more receptive to tory messages on fiscal prudence .
( see 5.08pm . )
stephen crabb , the welsh secretary , has said that the government will offer wales greater tax-varying powers .
he told the conference : our tax devolution will end the politics of the begging bowl in wales .
and so will begin a new era of responsible government in wales .
this is devolution with a purpose .
owen paterson , the former environment secretary , has said that the proposed eu/us trade deal is doomed unless sectors like agriculture are left out .
as the press association reports , paterson predicted the deal would founder on feta '' amid disputes over cheese-naming rights .
unless the proposal was narrowed to cover only sectors such as automotive and pharmaceuticals there was a serious danger that the whole initiative would collapse , he said .
it would be brilliant if we could pull ttip [ transatlantic trade and investment partnership ] off .
the prime minister reckons it 's worth £ 10bn to the uk economy .
but at the moment it is going to get stuck , bluntly .
it is going to go into the weeds the greeks are digging in on feta and the italians on parmesan there is absolutely no way [ the americans ] are going to budge on this .
this is established , it is a key product for many american consumers and producers and they are not going to move .
what we must not do is go for perfection and throw out the good .
that 's all from me for today .
thanks for the comments ( once we let them in . )
here 's a conservative conference reading list .
james forsyth at coffee house says the tories are quite confident '' they can beat mark reckless and ukip in the rochester byelection .
michael crick says much the same on his channel 4 news blog .
unlike clacton , i think mark reckless might struggle to win rochester at the by-election expected in a few weeks ' time .
he does n't seem to have the same personal vote as douglas carswell in clacton .
much will depend on what labour does .
will they run a token campaign , as in newark and clacton , and let ukip and the tories slug it out ?
that , i suspect , will be the inclination of the very cautious party labour has become under ed miliband .
but if labour put up a proper fight - as they have done in blair 's day - they could win rochester .
it was , after all , a labour seat until 2010 ( with bob marshall-andrews as their mp ) .
but for labour to win would rather underline the point tories are making - that defections to ukip merely help ed miliband and labour .
mike smithson at political betting says the bookies have ukip as favourites to win in rochester .
kevin gulliver at left foot forward dismisses yesterday 's housing announcement as a gimmick .

documents.title: ruth davidson hints more devolution could help tories in scotland
text: ruth davidson , the leader of the scottish conservatives , used her speech to the conference earlier to celebrate the no side 's victory in the independence referendum .
but she also said the conservatives should not be complacent .
davidson said the referendum result meant the status quo had been smashed '' .
it was impossible to ignore the views of the 1.6m people who voted against the union , she said .
this referendum sent a tremor through the fabric of this nation and the echoes of that tremor will last a lifetime .
we have to address the fact that - yes or no - people in scotland want change .
the status quo is smashed , there 's no going back , and the old rules do not apply .
she said giving the scottish parliament proper tax-raising powers would make the scottish government more accountable to voters .
although she did not say it directly , she also implied that this could make the scots more receptive to conservative messages about fiscal prudence .
for scotland , [ reform ] means having a parliament that - finally - has to look taxpayers in the eye .
right now , first ministers of scotland have a block grant transferred from westminster and their only concern is how t spend it .

this has allowed a nationalist government to spend 7 years telling the people of scotland that everything good in the country is down to them , for spending money on it , and everything bad is westminster 's fault for not handing over enough .
it makes every scottish election a spending competition , with no thought or regard of who the money comes from .
i am an old-fashioned tory .
i do n't believe there is any such thing as government money .
it does n't exist .
the only money that government has is the money it takes from the businesses and people of this country ; and we should never forget that .
and that 's something i want to ensure for scotland .
i want a scottish parliament that is in charge of raising more of the money it spends .
i want the working people of scotland to know - when they look at their monthly paycheck - that the right hand column is going straight to holyrood .
a more direct link between what is raised in scotland and what is spent in scotland .
less reliance on a block grant , and a more rigorous and fiscally responsible administration in edinburgh .
and when that happens .
when people see their earnings taxed , and that tax sent directly to bute house .
they will hold future first ministers to account .
ivan lewis , the shadow northern ireland secretary , says he was the one who thought of having another round of cross-party talks in northern ireland ( see 3.45pm ) first .
we welcome the uk and irish government 's decision to respond positively to the proposal i made at last week 's labour party conference .
it has been clear for some considerable time that the engagement of the two governments is essential if political stalemate in northern ireland is to end .
i hope that northern ireland 's political leaders will now rise to the challenge and make the necessary compromises which are essential if progress is to be made .

hague 's speech - snap verdict : william hague is one of the great political speakers of his age and , given that this marked the end of a conservative conference speaking career lasting almost 40 years , this was always going to be an event .
in the event , it was a fine speech , and it went down very well in the hall .
but it was no more than that .

as a colleague points out , good as he is as a platform speaker , hague is really at his best in the house of commons , where playing your audience counts for so much , and today 's speech was just a bit too reliant on some familiar hague rhetorical devices , like elaborate lists .
more importantly , it lacked a bit of fizz , because it was primarily about the past , whereas the best political speeches are about the present and the future .

the best bit came at the end , when he celebrated the conservative party 's progressive traditions and concluded with a plea for the party to maintain the inclusive spirt that enabled a comprehensive schoolboy from rotherham to rise to the top of it .
for much of his life hague was seen as someone on the party 's right ; perhaps its says so much about how the landscape has shifted that he ends his career sounding like a tory moderate .
hague says many of the things he has been most proud of have been about extending opportunity .
he is proud to have taken through the disability discrimination act as a disability minister .
and he is proud of having done that as a conservative .
as welsh secretary he promoted apprenticeships .
and as foreign secretary he restored the status of the foreign office , and put women 's rights at the heart of its work .
it is part of conservatism that half of the world 's population should not be neglected .
and he has tackled the use of rape as a weapon of war .
that 's because there is a moral dimension to conservatism , dating back to wilberforce and shaftesbury .
and , hague says , he did all this as a comprehensive schoolboy from rotherham .
so do n't let anyone say they are the party of privilege , or the south , he says .
he says his final message to the party is that it must always maintain its breadth of appeal , he says .
conservative values will be just as relevant in the 21st century , he says .
he says there are tories in the commons who will be the outstanding leaders of the future .
hague says further devolution to scotland turns the question of why scottish mps vote on english-only laws from an anomaly into an injustice .
his long-standing view has been that only english mps should vote on english laws , he says .
if no agreement can be reached , each party should take its case to the electorate , he says .
it is hypocritical and dishonest '' to say you want to give people a vote on europe , but to help labour , who would never give people a choice , hague says .
( that 's aimed at ukip , and mark reckless , obviously . )
hague says he has never seen a labour frontbench worse , weaker or more woeful .
you have to go back to michael foot to find a labour leadership less prepared to govern britain , he says .
he says , deep within the conservative party , lies a profound faith in democracy .
that is why it is having a referendum on the eu , he says .
labour has made the wrong choice .
anyone who votes for ukip next may is not voting for a referendum on europe , but obstructing one , he says .

documents.title: william hague 's speech
text: william hague is speaking now .
a short video of some of his greatest rhetoric hits has just been played .
he has addressed the conservative conference more times than anyone can remember , including him , he says .
but it is time to move on , he says .
over four decades he has watched the conservative party rescue the country not once , but twice , he says .
as a teenager he was inspired by margaret thatcher to enter politics .
and he was inspired by david cameron to return to frontline politics , he says .
he says over the last nine years he has witnessed cameron 's inexhaustible patience '' and steadily growing success '' .
richard harris ( @ rharris 11 ) an honour and privilege to hear the rt hon william hague address conference for the final time .
george osborne is introducing william hague now .
it will be hague 's last speech to a conservative conference as an mp .
hague is the greatest parliamentarian of his age , osborne says .

documents.title: villiers calls for resumption of cross-party talks in northern ireland
text: theresa villiers , the northern ireland secretary , had an announcement in her conference speech .
villiers called for the resumption of cross-party talks in northern ireland on the unresolved issues relating to flags , parades and unsolved crimes from the troubles .
she said her realistic assessment '' was that the time was right for talks , and that she would be talking to the five parties and the irish government about a format and an agenda .
she criticised northern ireland parties for not adopting welfare reform .
the nationalist parties were to blame , she said .
the conservatives are replacing the broken welfare system we inherited from labour with one based on common sense , that protects the vulnerable but which rewards work and is fairer for taxpayers .
welfare is devolved so northern ireland can maintain parity with the rest of the uk , or it can go it alone .

but no one should be in any doubt about the consequences of breaking parity , the social costs of propping up a welfare regime that too often fails the people it 's intended to help , and the massive financial costs of maintaining a separate and more expensive system .

the uk government has already agreed significant flexibilities to reflect northern ireland 's circumstances , but we have no more to give , and it 's now essential that the nationalist parties show they can make the hard choices of responsible government and allow welfare reform to be implemented .
lord ashcroft 's latest polling is now on his website .
he has published two reports : project blueprint phase 5 , which focuses on the views of conservative supporters or potential supporters : and research looking at tory/lib dem marginals .

documents.title: tory conference policy announcements - round-up
text: for the record , here are the conference-related conservative party policy announcements we 've had so far .
i 'll be updating this list every day .
1 - up to 100,000 new homes for first-time buyers under 40 .
2 - some 3m apprenticeships , funded by reducting the welfare cap and other welfare cuts .
there are more details here .
3 - stopping the european court of human rights over-ruling british courts .
chris grayling , the justice secretary , disclosed this in the telegraph on saturday , but details have not been announced .
4 - making mobile phone companies allow national roaming '' so that customers get a better signal .
sajid javid , the culture secretary , unveiled this in an interview in the daily mail on saturday .

documents.title: tories says cutting welfare cap would cost 70,000 families £ 40pw on average
text: the conservatives have now released more details of the costings for their plans to use welfare cuts to fund extra apprenticeships .
they say 70,000 families would be affected by the decision to reduce the welfare cap and that on average they would lose £ 40 a week .
some 3m apprenticeships would be created , they say .
here 's the party 's summary of what it is offering .
the plan will see 3 million apprenticeships created over the next parliament .

the plan also sees access to jobseeker 's allowance for 18-21 year olds abolished and replaced with a youth allowance , time-limited to six months , after which young people will have to take an apprenticeship , a traineeship , or do daily community work for their benefits .
this will be funded by reducing the household benefit cap from £ 26,000 per household to £ 23,000 .
it will also no longer be possible for most unemployed 18-21 year olds to claim housing benefit in order to leave home .
and we will continue to replace lower level , classroom-based further education courses with high quality apprenticeships .
and here are the costings the party has produced .
overall this is a cost neutral package .
in total we are making a new investment in young people of around £ 300m a year , which we will fund from the savings in this plan .
reducing the level of the household benefit cap saves around £ 135m a year .
removing hb from out of work 18-21 year olds saves around £ 120m a year after accounting for exemptions .
around £ 75m a year will be saved from young people moving off benefits more quickly as a result of these reforms .
the net cost of replacing classroom based fe with apprenticeships will be around £ 240m .
the cost of the new conditionality will be around £ 85m - that covers the 6 month time limit , daily community work , traineeships and additional work experience for 16-18 year olds .
and this is what the party says about what the impact of reducing the welfare cap to £ 23,000 would be .
dwp analysis suggests that lowering the cap to £ 23k would affect around 70,000 households in total .
around 40,000 would be newly capped , the remainder are already capped , but would now be capped at the lower level .

the maximum loss from lowering the cap , on top of existing losses from the current benefits cap , would be £ 60 per week , and around £ 40 on average , £ 25 per week on average for those newly capped .
according to buzzfeed , the journalist who entrapped brooks newmark used a selfie taken by a swedish model .
lord ashcroft is even saying labour could end up with a comfortable working majority , according to the sun 's kevin schofield .
kevin schofield ( @ schofieldkevin ) .
@ lordashcroft tells fringe at # cpc14 : `` the number of losses could extend to a point where labour have a comfortable working majority . ''

documents.title: lord ashcroft says his polling suggests labour heading for majority
text: while grant shapps speaks , lord ashcroft is unveiling some fresh polling about the party 's prospects at a fringe meeting .
i 'll post a link to the full findings when they 're up on his site .
in the meantime , here are some of the highlights from the meeting .

rowena mason ( @ rowenamason ) only 2 % of voters who did n't choose tories at last election would consider doing so next time , says lord ashcroft rowena mason ( @ rowenamason ) only 63 % of people who voted tory last time are planning to do so again , lord ashcroft says rowena mason ( @ rowenamason ) tories can afford to lose no more than 22 seats to labour but they are currently behind in 24 , says ashcroft kiran stacey ( @ kiranstacey ) pollster @ twitterid rick tells # cpc14 that carswell 's defection made nearly no impact on public view of how utd the party is .
kiran stacey ( @ kiranstacey ) only 63 % of tory 2010 voters now say they wd vote for the party , @ twitterid tells # cpc14 .
over half of those hv gone to ukip .
kiran stacey ( @ kiranstacey ) amazing stat from @ twitterid : half of the ppl the tories will target nxt yr believe austerity is no longer or was never needed .
# cpc14 kiran stacey ( @ kiranstacey ) verdict from @ twitterid : from results he has from marginals , looks like lab heading for a majority .
# cpc14

documents.title: grant shapps says mark reckless 'lied and lied and lied '
text: grant shapps starts with a strong attack on mark reckless .
conference , we have been betrayed .
every conservative in this hall , and everyone you represent : we all know : individual mps do n't succeed on their own .
they do so by standing on the shoulders of others .
your shoulders .
people who volunteered for mr reckless , they supported him as a conservative today , your trust has been abused .
you have been cheated .
but worse ; the people of rochester and strood have been cast aside as your party chairman , i share your deep sense of betrayal and anger .
we have been let down by somebody who has repeatedly lied to his constituents , and to you : who said one thing , and then did another .
last month , he looked us in the eye , and said only our prime minister could secure a say for the british people on europe .
last week , he insisted he would be campaigning for an outright conservative victory .
two days ago , he was busy leaving phone messages , claiming he was enthusiastic about joining us to campaign for rachel maclean here in birmingham today .
he lied and he lied and he lied .
the conference has now formally opened .
grant shapps , the party chairman is addressing it now .

documents.title: lunchtime summary
text: david cameron has indicated that he would be prepared to recommend to the british people that they should vote to leave the eu if he fails to secure major changes to britain 's membership terms after a tory victory in next year 's general election .

he made the concession in an interview on the andrew marr show in which he also tried to brush aside the damage to the party caused by its conference being overshadowed by a defection and a ministerial resignation .
cameron has unveiled a scheme that will bar childless 18 to 21-year-olds from housing benefit and remove their entitlement to jobseeker 's allowance after six months of failing to find a job .
mark reckless has defended his decision to defect from the conservatives to ukip , saying that he is the one trying to honour promises made to the electorate in 2010 and broken by cameron .

cameron has given his broadest hint yet that he wants to extend the fight against islamic state ( isis ) to syria and that only a lack of political consent at westminster is holding the government back .

cameron has said he will apologise again to the queen after he broke convention to tell the former new york mayor michael bloomberg that she purred down the line '' when he informed her that scotland had voted against independence .
nigel farage has ditched ukip 's proposal for a tax on luxury goods such as shoes and handbags just 48 hours after it was floated at the party 's autumn conference .
brooks newmark , who resigned as a minister yesterday after sending an inappropriate online to someone purporting to be a young female admirer , has said he has been a complete fool '' .
i do n't normally run caption competition , but this is crying out for one .
david cameron walks past a dalek as he arrives at the bbc studios in birmingham for his interview with andrew marr /reuters i 've updated the summary of david cameron 's marr interview at 10.34am .
but you may have to update the page for the update to appear .
some tories are attacking mark reckless on the grounds that he lied to them when he ruled out defecting .
on sky news this morning grant shapps said that he felt he had been lied '' to .
if people lie outright , then that 's a different matter .
most people have more integrity than that .
but nadine dorries , the conservative backbencher , told sky that she could understand why reckless was not honest with his colleagues .
anyone of any party who was about to defect and had to attend parliament for a major vote , if he was asked are you about to defect , would say no .
yes , he 's lied to his colleagues , but i 'm not going to join in this 'this man 's disgusting , treacherous and outrageous ' .
dorries said she thought what reckless had done was wrong '' because it increased the chances of a labour election victory .

she also said the party leadership was treating backbenchers with more consideration now , and she named two mps who have been touted as possible defectors who , she said , would definitely not be leaving the party .

i think [ the leadership 's relationship with backbenchers ] is repairing and i think david cameron is making great efforts to repair relationships with backbenchers i do know this much , for definite because he 's my daughter 's boyfriend of four years - chris kelly will not be defecting , not if he ever wants another roast dinner from me again .
brian binley is another person who the media have put forward as a person who is defecting .
brian binley , i could say with 99 % certainty will not be defecting .
i 've taken some of the quotes from politicshome .
nadine dorries meddle / rex features

documents.title: david davis says conservatives should be 'real tories '
text: david davis , the conservative backbencher , has written an article in the mail on sunday saying david cameron 's party modernisation '' strategy has been a mistake .
to put it at its kindest , the project to 'modernise ' the party failed to deliver electoral success .
at the same time , party membership collapsed from around 500,000 in 1992 , to about 100,000 in 2010 .
in short , we 're not in as strong a position as we would hope .

we 've flatlined in the polls since the 'omnishambles ' budget of 2012 at around 32 per cent , despite the economy recovering strongly trying to modernise the party without knowing why it needed to be modernised was like trying to fix a broken leg with radiotherapy .
you may end up doing more harm than good .

essentially , the modernisers absorbed the view of london 's metropolitan elite , which confuses social conservatism with bigotry , patriotism with xenophobia , or even racism , and equates an admiration for wealth creation with disdain for the poor and even carelessness about the future of the planet .
nonsensical views , but remarkably common in the upper reaches of parts of london society .
on the sunday politics , when andrew neil put it to him that this article amounted to an exocet '' directed at david cameron , davis said it was more of a lever '' , an attempt to influence policy .
the conservatives needed to be more authentically conservative , he said .
you have to be real tories .

we need to take a far more robust stance on a whole series of policies - whether it is english votes , lower taxes , deregulation - normal , conventional , conservative policies that have worked for a couple of hundred years and have n't stopped working yet .
david davis saker / rex features
grant shapps , the conservative party chairman , is going to announce that the party membership has risen by almost 12 % , conservativehome reports .
he will claim it has gone up to 149,800 .

documents.title: daniel hannan rules out defecting to ukip
text: daniel hannan , the conservative mep , says he wo n't be defecting to ukip .
daniel hannan ( @ danhannanmep ) i have immense respect for @ twitterid as an mp and as a friend .
i wish him all the best , but i wo n't be following him to ukip .
there was speculation he would .
see 9.21am .
tim montgomerie , the former conservativehome editor , has named another two tories as potential defectors .
tim montgomerie ( @ timmontgomerie ) reckless repeatedly lied to tory whips about defecting - making them super nervy now .
gordon henderson & adam holloway top their watch list .

documents.title: 45 % of tory councillors would vote to leave eu , poll finds
text: conservatives councillors are roughly split down the middle over whether britain should leave the eu , a poll for the sunday politics found .
some 45 % said britain should leave , and 39 % said they would vote to stay in .
robbie gibb ( @ robbiegibb ) excl : 45 % of conservative councillors would vote to leave eu if referendum tomorrow .
39 % would vote to stay in # bbcsp/comres ( 2/5 ) the other findings were interesting too .
robbie gibb ( @ robbiegibb ) excl : 30 % of conservative councillors support an electoral pact with ukip at the general election .
63 % opposed # bbcsp /comres ( 1/5 ) robbie gibb ( @ robbiegibb ) excl : 31 % of conservative councillors believe david cameron was right to pursue legalising gay marriage .
60 % disagree # bbcdp/comres ( 3/5 ) robbie gibb ( @ robbiegibb ) excl : 86 % of conservative cllrs say immigration is too high .

49 % think climate change is happening but humans not mainly responsible ( 4/5 ) robbie gibb ( @ robbiegibb ) excl : 56 % of conservative councillors say spending cuts the government have announced so far have not gone far enough # bbcdp/comres ( 5/5 )

documents.title: mark reckless 's interview on the sunday politics - summary
text: here are the key points from mark reckless 's interview on the sunday politics .
reckless said he was defecting to ukip because the conservatives had not kept their promises .
you heard the prime minister just now say the conservative-led government was dealing with the deficit and cutting immigration .
the reality is we 've increased the national debt by more in five years than even labour managed in 13 and immigration is now back up to the levels we saw under labour .
he wanted to keep those promises , he said .

i believe in the promises i made in 2010 and i want to keep my word to my electorate , not least to deal with the deficit , cut immigration , to reform our political system , to localise powers back to our community , particularly over house-building , and the government has broken its word on all those things .
he brushed aside complaints that he had lied to colleagues about defection .

when andrew neil played him the voicemail he left with the tories on friday night saying he would campaign for the party in birmingham ( see 11.32am ) , he replied you ca n't discuss these things in advance .
you have to make a decision and you have to move at a particular point in time .
he said that , having opposed ukip in the past , he had decided to join them because they were attracting so much widespread support .
people , including him , found nigel farage inspiring '' , he said .

what 's changed is that people in ukip are coming from labour and the liberal democrats and people are just so disillusioned by the political parties in westminster and the political parties there , that they have n't voted in a generation .
those are the people nigel farage is inspiring and frankly he 's inspired me .
he said the ukip conference was more inspiring than the conservative one because it contained people passionate about politics as an instrument of change .
when i first went to conservative conferences about 20 years ago , there was some enthusiasm for politics .
people thought they could change things .
i remember norman tebbit speaking against the maastricht treaty and there was real politics at conference .
but i do n't think you will see that birmingham this week .
it 's mainly pr people , lobbyists , very few ordinary members .

and at doncaster what you saw was 2,000 people , some of whom had saved up for months just to get the rail ticket to doncaster and to pay to stay there , who believe in ukip , who believe in nigel farage , who believe in the people who are joining him , the team behind him , as agents of change who can actually deal with the political class in westminster who have let people down .
mark reckless with nigel farage ( right ) yesterday tang/rex
nigel farage , the ukip leader , this morning killed off an idea floated by his treasury spokesman just two days ago .
( see 9.12am . )
that might look a bit shambolic , but on radio 5 live john steve crowther , ukip 's chairman , said that if the party was not slick '' , that was a bonus .
if sometimes we are a little bit hard-edged or sometimes we stub our toe , i do n't think that 's a problem .

it 's part of our brand , frankly , it 's part of what ukip is i believe that it is true that ukip is liked by its electorate because it is not always as slick and as polished as the other political parties .
the sunday politics played what it said was a voicemail message left by mark reckless saying he would be campaigning with the tories at a roadtrip event at the conference .
you can listen to it here .
overnight the conservatives announced plans to cut the welfare cap by £ 3,000 , taking it down to £ 23,000 , to raise funds to pay for apprenticeships .
the joseph rowntree foundation says this is a bad idea .
this is from chris goulden , its head of poverty research .
providing routes to secure , well-paying work is the right approach to reducing poverty .
but this should not come at the expense of people in receipt of out of work benefits .
the household benefit cap may be a popular but in fact it does little to cut the deficit .
the existing cap affects just 40,000 families , cutting their incomes by £ 93 a week on average .
if we want to reduce the welfare bill , we need to address the underlying drivers of poverty ; the high cost of housing , low pay and barriers to work such as affordable childcare .
we need all parties to deliver a comprehensive strategy to reduce the high levels of poverty across the uk .
building on a stronger labour market with more and better paying jobs , lower living costs and reforms to markets is the best route to achieving this .
q : does n't your defection prove that ukip is a party full of tories ?
reckless says at the ukip conference in doncaster there were ordinary people passionate about politics .
that is what conservative conferences were like in the past , when norman tebbit was speaking against maastricht .
but now conservative conferences are not like this .
they are just full of pr people .
q : after the next election the prime minister will either be david cameron or ed miliband .
who do you want ?
reckless says he wants as many ukip policies as possible .
and that 's it .
i 'll summarise the key points shortly .
q : in may you said nigel farage posed the most serious threat to a conservative government .
reckless says voting ukip means getting ukip .
what has changed is that more people are attracted to ukip .
nigel farage has inspired people who have been excluded from politics .
and he says farage has inspired him .
q : but you said it would harm a tory victory .
reckless says he does not want a tory victory now .
he wants those promises kept .
david cameron has had his chance .
he has not kept his promises .
q : are n't you just doing this to safe your seat ?
reckless asks if neil really thinks this is the easy option .
it will be an unpredictable byelection , he says .
he is moving to ukip because many people who voted tory in the past have been let down .
he is being open and honest , he says .
i 'm trying to do the right thing by my constituents .
andrew neil plays a voicemail that mark reckless left with cchq about coming to birmingham to campaign for the tories .
q : why did you lie ?
reckless says he is not sure if the whole message was played ?
you can not announce these things in advance , he says .

documents.title: mark reckless 's intervew
text: q : why did you lie to your conservative colleagues ?
mark reckless says he is keeping faith with the promises he made to his electorate , on cutting the benefit , dealing with immigration , and giving powers to local communities .
he will give voters a say in a byelection , he says .
mark reckless will be interviews by andrew neil on the sunday politics shortly .
i 'll be covering that in detail .

documents.title: brooks newmark says he has been 'a complete fool '
text: brooks newmark has been talking about the events that led to his resignation as a minister yesterday .
chris mason ( @ chrismasonbbc ) brooks newmark tells me : 'i have been a complete fool .
i have no one to blame but myself . '
chris mason ( @ chrismasonbbc ) brooks newmark : 'i 've hurt those i care about most .
i am so so sorry .
but i just need time with my family i hope you can understand that . '
buzzfeed has a very good account of how newmark was set up .
finally the comments have been switched on .
i thought i had put them on earlier , but forgot the press the right button .
i 'm very sorry about that .

documents.title: david cameron 's interview on the marr show - summary
text: here is a summary of the main points from the andrew marr interview .
cameron appeared to conceded that his attempts to renegotiate britain 's relationship with the eu might fail to live up to his expectations .
previously , when asked if he would recommend britain leaving in the event of not getting what he wanted , he has refused to speculate on this , saying he goes into a negotiation hoping to succeed .
today he adopted a slightly different tone .

if i do n't achieve that it will be for the british public to decide whether to stay in or get out i have said this all my political life : if i thought that it was n't in britain 's interest to be in the european union , i would n't argue for us to be in it .
he said the tories wanted to effectively abolish youth unemployment '' by stopping people under the age of 21 claiming unemployment benefit .
instead young people should be working or learning , he said .
but he said that his proposed welfare cuts for this age group would not affect young people with children .
at heart , i want us to effectively abolish youth unemployment .
i want us to end the idea that aged 18 you can leave school , go and leave home , claim unemployment benefit and claim housing benefit .
we should n't be offering that choice to young people ; we should be saying , 'you should be earning or learning ' we are not talking about those people with children .
this is about single people aged 18 to 21 .
he said the welfare cap had succeeded into encouraging people to find work .
what we have found with the welfare cap is it has been a policy which has worked and worked very well .
people said this would cause chaos , that people would have to move across the country , that it would n't work .
what has happened is a lot of those families have gone into work , have found a job and it 's been a policy which has helped them with their lives .

all the evidence is the cap is too loose , particularly in some parts of the country , so bringing it down to £ 23,000 saves money , will mean more families getting into work and what i want to see , the plan we have for britain , is to spend less on welfare and more on helping people into work .
he said that mark reckless 's defection to ukip was senseless and counter-productive '' .
he said had not specifically '' been aware of reckless ' plan to defect , but that the mp was someone who very rarely votes for the government '' .
and he said the defection was counter-productive because it made a conservative government after 2015 less likely '' .
these things are frustrating and , frankly , they are counter-productive and rather senseless .

if you want to have a european referendum , if you want to have immigration controlled , if you want to get the deficit down , if you want to build a stronger britain that we can be proud of , there is only one option and that is to have a conservative government after the next election .
this was not an ideal start to the conservative conference , cameron conceded .
but he said yesterday 's events did not alter the fundamental choice facing voters .
i have to be admit , it 's not been an ideal start , i think it 's fair to say that .

the truth is , these things , frustrating as they are , they do n't change the fundamental choice at the election , which is do you want to continue with the long term economic plan that is working , or do you want to lurch off with ed miliband with no plan , no leadership , no ideas about the economy .
he said that talking about his conversation with the queen about scotland was one of those mistakes that make you kick yourself very hard '' .
he had apologised to the queen , and would do so again in person , he said .
[ it was ] one of those moments when you look back and kick yourself very hard .
it was not a conversation i should have had , i am extremely sorry and very embarrassed about it .
i have made my apologies and i think i 'll probably be making some more .
he said boris johnson would have to wait until after he had finished his term as london mayor before he could take a cabinet job .
yes , of course [ johnson could have a cabinet job ] but he has got to finish his term as mayor of london , i know that 's what he wants to do .

and i believe you can be a member of parliament and mayor of london and do a very effective job , but once he 's finished that then he 's a star , and as i 've always said , i want to have the stars in the team .
he reaffirmed his commitment to honour his promise to give scotland more devolution .
peter henley ( @ bbcpeterh ) it 's not been an ideal start to conference pm tells # marr # con14
i 'm sorry comments were left off earlier .
that was a mistake .
they 're on now .
q : how do you feel about comparisions with john major 's conference ?
cameron says it is not an ideal start to the conference .
but these things do not change the fundamental choice : do people want the conservatives with their economic plan , or do you want ed miliband .
and that 's it .
i 'll post a summary .
q : was the queen furious about your comment .
what were you thinking of ?
cameron says it is one of those moments that you think of and kick yourself very hard .
he says he has apologised , and will apologise again .
q : would you like boris johnson back in the cabinet ?
yes , says cameron .
but he has to finish his term as mayor of london first .
q : are we moving to a situation where no one under 21 gets any benefit ?
it 's not quite as simple as that , as cameron .
but he wants to abolish youth unemployment .
you should not be on housing benefit or unemployment benefit at that age .
you should be earning or learning .
q : around half of these people have children .
cameron says he is not talking about cuts for people with children .
but people should be earning or learning , he says .
the welfare system should prioritise work , he says .
q : you want to cut the welfare cap by £ 3,000 .
how do you know people will be able to cope ?
cameron says the welfare cap has worked .
it has got more people into work .
he wants to use the money from welfare savings to fund 3m apprentices .
q : will more scottish devolution and english devolution happen at the same time ?
cameron says he wants to do both .
but the pledge to scotland must be kept .
q : you and labour will fall out over england .
we may well do , says cameron .
but as prime minister , he will deliver both : proper scottish devolution , and an answer to the english question .
q : the scots will get devolution under all circumstances .
yes , says cameron .
q : do you want an english parliament ?
no , says cameron .
the last thing people want is another expensive parliament .
either there will be an outbreak of good sense '' from his opponents .
but he doubts it .
so the tory plans will be in the manifesto .
q : what if you do n't get what you want ?
cameron says , if you go into a negotiation , you should set out your goals .
if he does not get what he wants , it will be up to the public to decide .
q : can you imagine saying we should leave ?
cameron says , if he did not think it was in britain 's interests to be in the eu , he would say so .
q : so , if you do n't get what you want , you will recommend leaving ?
cameron says he thinks he will get what he wants .
but it will be up to the public to decide .
q : do you want to end free movement of people ?
cameron says immigration will be at the heart of his renegotiation strategy .
he does not want people moving to the uk to claim benefits .
q : but you ca n't do anything about the free movement of people .
cameron says the right to travel to work is one thing .
but coming to the uk to claim benefits , or working and sending benefits back to another country , is another thing .
if he is pm , these things will happen .
they wo n't happen under ed miliband .
q : are you determined to keep the uk in the eu ?
cameron says his plan is to keep the uk in a reformed eu .
q : did you know mark reckless was doing to defect ?
not specifically , says cameron .
but reckless was someone who rarely voted with the government .
what he did was counter-productive and rather senseless '' .
q : why are you losing these people ?
you 'll have to ask them .
q : they say you are not a proper conservative .
cameron says he does not agree .
they want to leave the eu , he says .
he does not .
but he is the only person offering a referendum .
that is why these defections are senseless .
q : will we have to send advisers to iraq to help the iraqi government ?
cameron says there are already britons out there helping and advising , in iraq and kurdistan .
q : you could have special forces trying to rescue hostages .
cameron says he never comments on special forces .
he oversees efforts to rescue hostages personally .
q : is n't there a danger of getting sucked in ?
that 's an argument for doing nothing , says cameron .
we have a choice .
we can either stand back .
or we can have a comprehensive strategy .
q : general richards said this morning that you can not win a war without getting involved on the ground .
cameron says he wanted to take to the commons a plan that would attract consensus .
q : there are three armies : the peshmerga , the iraqi army , who have been useless , and the free syrian army , who are not strong .
so who will defeat isis on the grounds ?
cameron says he wants to build up the syrian opposition .
in syria there has to be a transition from the brutal dictator to a representative government .
q : but the only organised army facing isis is assad 's army .
will we have to do a deal with assad ?
no , says cameron .
assad is part of the problem .
there needs to be a new , representative government in syria .
q : isis are not like an army .
george galloway made the point they sit among civilians .
so wo n't civilians be killed ?
cameron says he does not accept that .
there are times when they are out in the open .
they can be stopped .
but if marr is making the point that there needs to be an uprising of sunni tribes against isis ( cameron calls it isil , but our style is isis ) , he agrees .

documents.title: david cameron 's interview on the marr show
text: q : if isis are pushed into syria , would you order the raf into syria without another vote ?
david cameron says if he felt he could avert a humanitarian disaster somewhere by ordering action quickly , he would do so , and go back to the commons later .
he says he made this point in the commons to show that , although he backs the idea of the commons having a vote , there could always be exceptions .

documents.title: a mark reckless reading list
text: the david cameron interview is coming up any minute now .
since mark reckless is likely to feature prominently , here is a quick reckless reading list .
mark reckless 's speech to the ukip conference on saturday explaning why he defected .
an account from isabel hardman of what reckless said to journalists in a briefing about this defection .
nigel farage 's interview on the andrew marr show is being broadcast now .
he says the wags ' tax '' idea was never put forward as party policy .
but other ideas announced on friday , such as the plan to take many people out of the 40p tax bracket by lifting the threshold , were firm commitments , he said .
the spectator 's james forsyth says a third tory defection to ukip seems to be on the cards .
james forsyth ( @ jgforsyth ) senior tories now regard @ twitterid defection as a question of when not if .
word is he 's gone dark since reckless ' quit daniel hannan , the conservative mep , is an arch eurosceptic who is very close to the two tory mps who have already defected .
he wrote a ( very interesting ) book with douglas carswell , and , at mark reckless 's wedding , he was best man .

documents.title: ukip u-turn over `` wags ' tax ''
text: two days ago , at the ukip conference , patrick o'flynn , the party 's economic spokesman , floated the idea of a new tax on luxury goods like designers shoes and handbags .
it was dubbed a wag '' tax in the media .
but the wags are safe .
nigel farage , the ukip leader , has killed the idea .
he did so in an interview on the andrew marr show , being broadcast shortly but recorded in advance .
farage said o'flynn 's proposal was no more than a discussion point '' .
i am very happy to give the freedom to our spokesmen and spokeswomen to float ideas but i 'm pretty certain that while i 'm leader that will not be in our manifesto .
as far as i am concerned it 's dead .
it was a discussion point yesterday .
it is n't going to happen .
in an interview in the sun on sunday david cameron says that he did consider whether he would have to resign if scotland voted to leave the uk .
but he explains why he said in advance that he would not do so .
i thought about resigning because i care so passionately about this issue .
if the vote had been for scotland to have left the uk , i genuinely would have been heartbroken .
i would have felt winded and wounded .
emotionally , one would have thought , 'i 'm so saddened by this .
i find it difficult to go on ' .
of course , i contemplated having to go .
i thought , 'what 's the right thing to do ? '
in many ways the easiest thing would be to say , 'i feel wounded by this ' and walk away .
i 'm sure it would have been absolutely awful .
in the end i came to the conclusion that would not have been the right thing to do .
at the conservative conference the telegraph gives away free newspapers .
in normal circumstances the party might be grateful , but today members probably feel rather differently .
andrewsparrow ( @ andrewsparrow ) paper bin at the conservative conference it 's a strong word , crisis , much over-used by journalists , but this morning it feels appropriate .
even at the most wretched moments of his premiership , i do n't think john major ever suffered a defection and a ministerial resignation on the same day .
ingeniously , sky news this morning is trying to turn a double crisis into a triple crisis by highlighting polling showing that nigel farage now has a higher approval rating than david cameron .

the poll is probably not hugely significant , and brooks newmark 's resignation ( which was prompted by an entrapment exercise which seems hard to justify on public interest grounds - but that 's a matter for another day ) is relatively trivial .
but the defection of a second mp to ukip is very big story indeed because , as fraser nelson explains in a good blog for coffee house , it shows that a fundamental realignment is underway .
even dan hodges is now admitting labour could win the election .
the crisis has also overshadowed an important announcement from the conservatives about using further welfare cuts to fund more apprenticeships .
so , there will be a lot to talk about when david cameron appears on the andrew marr show within the next hour .
here 's the agenda for the day around 9.30am : david cameron gives an interview to the andrew marr show .
2pm : grant shapps , the conservative chairman , opens the conference .

2.30pm : session on our united kingdom , with contributions from theresa villiers , the northern ireland secretary , stephen crabb , the welsh secretary , david mundell , the scotland office minister , andrew rt davies , leader of the welsh conservatives , and ruth davidson , leader of the scottish conservatives .
3.30pm : william hague , the leader of the commons , speaks .
i 'll be covering all the conference news , as well as bringing reaction and highlighting the best comment and analysis on the web .
if you want to follow me on twitter , i 'm on @ twitterid .

bulletin.text: Brooks Newmark says he has been 'a complete fool'
